items.title: 10 songs for 2023
items.content_text:
For four years now, I’ve made a playlist of my top songs every month. The idea was to create a musical diary of sorts. When I listen to December 2019, some of the thoughts I was having at the time come rushing back. As my December 2023 playlist comes to an end, I want to start a new tradition of reflecting on the 10 songs that defined my year, roughly in chronological order.
“Eat That Up, It’s Good for You” by Two Door Cinema Club 2010 on repeat in 2023.
“Head on Fire” by Griff & Sigrid I had this on repeat on the train during my trip to Japan in April.
“Something for your M.I.N.D.” by Superorganism I heard about this band through a coworker. The song is kinda awesome.
“LAS BABYS” by Aitana It was a fun summer song.
“Let’s Sort the Whole Thing Out” by Carly Rae Jepsen I went to the Anything to Be With You tour in August at Pier 17 in NYC, conveniently a 5 minute walk from my office. This song is so much fun live.
“Praise You” by Fatboy Slim I’m half sure this song was played at a company all hands meeting, and it wouldn’t be the first song from work to make my listening rotation, not so much embarassing for me honestly. I think they just pick great music.
“我相信” by “楊培安” I didn’t have as many Chinese songs in my Spotify Wrapped playlist this year (sad). The ones I did mainly came from friends. I heard this one on a weekend trip to the Poconos with friends.
“Modern Girl” by Bleachers My #1 song of the year! This song should’ve topped every US hits chart.
“That’s Where I Am” by Maggie Rogers Made my top songs in 2022. Back again for 2023.
“You’re a God” by Vertical Horizon I’m wrapping the year up with this old classic on repeat.

I’m wrapping the year up with this old classic on repeat.

items.title: What I did this summer
items.content_text:
Sometimes I think I never go out, but looking back, I did a lot this summer.
NYC # Went to Xiang Hotpot Ate Japanese food at Industry City Went to karaoke at Cafe Mix Got soup dumplings in Brooklyn Heights Ate the fried tangyuan at Wenwen Did the seafood boil with some coworkers at Momofuku Ssam Bar before it closed Ate skewers at NONONO Played mini golf at Swingers Got drinks at Pine & Polk Got drinks at Singlish Played cards in Prospect Park Tried Bagel Pub in Park Slope Went to a Brooklyn Contra event in Park Slope Ate ice cream at The Social in Prospect Heights River cruise for a team offsite River cruise for an intern/intern manager event Saw Carly Rae Jepsen at Pier 17 Ate at Olio e Più Drinks at Bangia Lunch at Shan in Cobble Hill Dinner at Yemen Cafe Fruit milk slush at Debutea Played basketball at Berry Playground Watched Barbie Watched Gran Turismo Went to the Meta office for dinner Took the Metro North upstate to Beacon Tried Mabu Cafe Went to Kura Revolving Sushi Bar in Fort Lee Played mahjong Watched the Caroline Wozniacki vs. Petra Kvitova match at the US Open Seattle # Flew to Seattle for a few days Dinner at Tamari Bar Dessert at Baiten Walked around Green Lake Bought mead at the Sunday Ballard Farmers Market Lunch at Portage Bay Cafe in Ballard Watched boats go through the Ballard Locks Bought wine at Pike Place Market Tried the cookies at Hello Robin in University Village Browsed The Elliot Bay Book Company Bought souvenirs at Standard Goods Brunch at Nue Sat around Lake Union Ordered an ube latte and ube cookie at Hood Famous Saw multiple friends I hadn’t seen in 1+ years Bay Area # Hung out with friends for a few days Saw Taylor Swift in Santa Clara
items.content_html:
Sometimes I think I never go out, but looking back, I did a lot this summer.

NYC #

  1. Went to Xiang Hotpot
  2. Ate Japanese food at Industry City
  3. Went to karaoke at Cafe Mix
  4. Got soup dumplings in Brooklyn Heights
  5. Ate the fried tangyuan at Wenwen
  6. Did the seafood boil with some coworkers at Momofuku Ssam Bar before it closed
  7. Ate skewers at NONONO
  8. Played mini golf at Swingers
  9. Got drinks at Pine & Polk
  10. Got drinks at Singlish
  11. Played cards in Prospect Park
  12. Tried Bagel Pub in Park Slope
  13. Went to a Brooklyn Contra event in Park Slope
  14. Ate ice cream at The Social in Prospect Heights
  15. River cruise for a team offsite
  16. River cruise for an intern/intern manager event
  17. Saw Carly Rae Jepsen at Pier 17
  18. Ate at Olio e Più
  19. Drinks at Bangia
  20. Lunch at Shan in Cobble Hill
  21. Dinner at Yemen Cafe
  22. Fruit milk slush at Debutea
  23. Played basketball at Berry Playground
  24. Watched Barbie
  25. Watched Gran Turismo
  26. Went to the Meta office for dinner
  27. Took the Metro North upstate to Beacon
  28. Tried Mabu Cafe
  29. Went to Kura Revolving Sushi Bar in Fort Lee
  30. Played mahjong
  31. Watched the Caroline Wozniacki vs. Petra Kvitova match at the US Open

Seattle #

  1. Flew to Seattle for a few days
  2. Dinner at Tamari Bar
  3. Dessert at Baiten
  4. Walked around Green Lake
  5. Bought mead at the Sunday Ballard Farmers Market
  6. Lunch at Portage Bay Cafe in Ballard
  7. Watched boats go through the Ballard Locks
  8. Bought wine at Pike Place Market
  9. Tried the cookies at Hello Robin in University Village
  10. Browsed The Elliot Bay Book Company
  11. Bought souvenirs at Standard Goods
  12. Brunch at Nue
  13. Sat around Lake Union
  14. Ordered an ube latte and ube cookie at Hood Famous
  15. Saw multiple friends I hadn’t seen in 1+ years

Bay Area #

  1. Hung out with friends for a few days
  2. Saw Taylor Swift in Santa Clara

items.title: How I learned to ride a bike
items.summary: The simple story of how I learned to ride a bike
items.content_text:
First attempt # When I was 8, my parents tried to teach me to ride a bike. I started with training wheels. One day, I fell off my bike (with training wheels), and the wound took a month to heal. I never rode that bike again.
Second attempt # My freshman year of college, my friends and I were walking around campus at midnight. Specifcially, we were in between the Physical Sciences Building and Klarman Hall. This was 2018, when Lime Bike was still in Ithaca. We spotted a bike on the sidewalk and decided to use it. If you’re familiar with PSB, you know it’s on top of a hill, and my friends took turns riding up and down the hill. They came back to the sidewalk and told me it’s not that hard to ride a bike, so I gave it a shot (on the sidewalk, not the hill). I was able to steadily ride the bike for, a minute? But, it didn’t stick.
Third attempt # Summer of 2019, I was in Beijing. My friends and I were in Wudaokou, and they wanted to bike to the Bird’s Nest. To give you an idea of how long that would take, the distance is around 3 miles or 5 km. I was a little scared, but I figured I could learn along the way. My friends had trouble describing how to ride the bike to me, but if I didn’t figure it out, I would have been left behind. I kept trying to “balance while moving” as someone described it, and eventually I got the hang of it. And then I learned what everyone meant when they said you learn it once and never forget it.
That’s how I learned to ride a bike the summer of 2019 in Beijing.
items.content_html:
First attempt #

When I was 8, my parents tried to teach me to ride a bike. I started with training wheels. One day, I fell off my bike (with training wheels), and the wound took a month to heal. I never rode that bike again.

Second attempt #

My freshman year of college, my friends and I were walking around campus at midnight. Specifcially, we were in between the Physical Sciences Building and Klarman Hall. This was 2018, when Lime Bike was still in Ithaca. We spotted a bike on the sidewalk and decided to use it. If you’re familiar with PSB, you know it’s on top of a hill, and my friends took turns riding up and down the hill. They came back to the sidewalk and told me it’s not that hard to ride a bike, so I gave it a shot (on the sidewalk, not the hill). I was able to steadily ride the bike for, a minute? But, it didn’t stick.

Third attempt #

Summer of 2019, I was in Beijing. My friends and I were in Wudaokou, and they wanted to bike to the Bird’s Nest. To give you an idea of how long that would take, the distance is around 3 miles or 5 km. I was a little scared, but I figured I could learn along the way. My friends had trouble describing how to ride the bike to me, but if I didn’t figure it out, I would have been left behind. I kept trying to “balance while moving” as someone described it, and eventually I got the hang of it. And then I learned what everyone meant when they said you learn it once and never forget it.

That’s how I learned to ride a bike the summer of 2019 in Beijing.

items.title: Every match I watched in person at the US Open
items.content_text:
2021 # Fall break in NYC! Went back to Ithaca, then drove back down again for the final.
Carlos Alcaraz vs Stefanos Tsitsipas | 2021 US Open Round 3 Leylah Fernandez vs Naomi Osaka | 2021 US Open Round 3 Mixed Doubles Final | Krawczyk/Salisbury vs Olmos/Arevalo | 2021 US Open Emma Raducanu vs Leylah Fernandez Highlights | 2021 US Open Final 2022 # No more driving 5 hours upstate!
Hradecka/Noskova vs. Williams/Williams | 2022 US Open Round 1 Fabio Fognini vs. Rafael Nadal | 2022 US Open Round 2 Petra Kvitova vs. Jessica Pegula | 2022 US Open Round 4 Frances Tiafoe vs. Rafael Nadal | 2022 US Open Round 4 Iga Swiatek vs. Jule Niemeier | 2022 US Open Round 4 Victoria Azarenka vs. Karolina Pliskova | 2022 US Open Round 4
items.content_html:
2021 #

Fall break in NYC! Went back to Ithaca, then drove back down again for the final.

  • Carlos Alcaraz vs Stefanos Tsitsipas | 2021 US Open Round 3
  • Leylah Fernandez vs Naomi Osaka | 2021 US Open Round 3
  • Mixed Doubles Final | Krawczyk/Salisbury vs Olmos/Arevalo | 2021 US Open
  • Emma Raducanu vs Leylah Fernandez Highlights | 2021 US Open Final

2022 #

No more driving 5 hours upstate!

  • Hradecka/Noskova vs. Williams/Williams | 2022 US Open Round 1
  • Fabio Fognini vs. Rafael Nadal | 2022 US Open Round 2
  • Petra Kvitova vs. Jessica Pegula | 2022 US Open Round 4
  • Frances Tiafoe vs. Rafael Nadal | 2022 US Open Round 4
  • Iga Swiatek vs. Jule Niemeier | 2022 US Open Round 4
  • Victoria Azarenka vs. Karolina Pliskova | 2022 US Open Round 4
